results.title: Emulation of Bad Street Brawler for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Originally released as Bop’n Rumble, and known as Street Hassle in Australia. This single-player beat-‘em-up style game lets players control Duke Davis, who goes from stage to stage beating up gangsters that get in his way, dressed in a yellow tank top, sunglasses, and yellow pants. He is described as a former punk rocker and the “world’s coolest” martial artist.

Original game developed by Beam Software Pty., Ltd. for Commodore 64. Published in 1987 by Mindscape Inc.
results.title_for_label: Bad Street Brawler [computer game] for Commodore 64 [harvested game emulation file]

results.title: Emulation of America's Cup Challenge for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
America’s Cup Challenge is a one to two player competitive sports simulation. The included manual contains a lot of information about the America’s Cup including yachting terminology, race legs, wind angles, sails and weather conditions. The player controls the crew of a racing yacht using the joystick, chosing the type of sail at the start of the race and then switching between three different modes, helmsman, sails selection and winching. As Helmsman, players control the yacht’s direction. Sail selection allows players to move the angle of the sail’s boom and the level of use of the spinnaker or genoa. The manual advises the use of a good quality robust joystick.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/arnies-americas-cup-challenge/
Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Micro Forté Pty. Ltd. for Commodore 64, published by Electronic Arts (USA) and U.S. Gold (Europe) in 1986.

results.title: Alt-Right Arabesque
results.credit_line:
Baiden Pailthorpe
Single-channel video, 3 mins.
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Single channel video, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Alt-Right Arabesque continues Pailthorpe’s interest in the performing digital body, yet with a new focus on the aesthetics of the resurgent and re-branded fascism (the so-called Alt-right). The sickly-looking protagonist in this work symbolises the infamous 4chan moderator or frequent Reddit user, who spectacularly twirls en arabesque in box-fresh Nike Airmax. A variety of surreal political imagery, visual references and cinematic techniques long associated with fascism and propaganda in the history of cinema are combined in this animation to create a strange and intense response to the overwhelming weirdness of 2016.
[Source: https://sydneycontemporary.com.au/video17/
Last accessed 2/9/2020]

results.title: Rabbit-Proof Fence
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Christine Olsen, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Jabel Films, Premium Movie Partnership and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ is based on the true story of three First Nations girls, Molly, Daisy and Gracie, who in 1931 were forcibly removed from their mothers and home in Jigalong, Western Australia, and sent to a settlement 2000 kilometres away to be trained as domestic servants and inducted into White culture. Upon arrival, the girls are instantly averse to their strange, rather grotesque new world, and decide to take matters into their own hands by attempting an escape and return home. Here begins the girls’ seemingly eternal, epic journey across the harsh Australian desert landscape, with all odds against them except for a rabbit-proof fence as their guide home. In a moving finale, they are reunited with their mothers and, significantly, their culture. Though it is a specifically Australian story (the Stolen Generations and the White Australia Policy), director Phillip Noyce tells it in such a way that emphasises universal qualities of tragedy and heroism. He opts for an even-handed portrayal of the past, steering clear of images of oppression or subjugation and any chastising of White Culture, and instead emphasises optimism and survival. The film is adapted from a book of the same title by author, Doris Pilkington, daughter of the real-life Molly and ‘Stolen Generation’ victim. Christopher Doyle’s photography and Peter Gabriel’s score give spiritual resonance to moments of emotional intensity, such as the tearing of children from their mothers, the crossing of a daunting barren landscape and the homecoming embrace between mother and daughter. Stars Everlyn Sampi, Tianna Sansbury, Laura Monaghan, Kenneth Branagh, David Gupilil, Deborah Mailman. Also includes the 35-minute documentary “Following the Rabbit Proof Fence” by Darlene Johnson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phil Noyce, Christine Olsen, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Jabel Films, Premium Movie Partnership and South Australian Film Corporation

Christopher Doyle’s photography and Peter Gabriel’s score give spiritual resonance to moments of emotional intensity, such as the tearing of children from their mothers, the crossing of a daunting barren landscape and the homecoming embrace between mother and daughter. Stars Everlyn Sampi, Tianna Sansbury, Laura Monaghan, Kenneth Branagh, David Gupilil, Deborah Mailman. Also includes the 35-minute documentary “Following the Rabbit Proof Fence” by Darlene Johnson.
description_for_label: ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ is based on the true story of three First Nations girls, Molly, Daisy and Gracie, who in 1931 were forcibly removed from their mothers and home in Jigalong, Western Australia, and sent to a settlement 2000 kilometres away to be trained as domestic servants and inducted into White culture. Upon arrival, the girls are instantly averse to their strange, rather grotesque new world, and decide to take matters into their own hands by attempting an escape and return home. Here begins the girls’ seemingly eternal, epic journey across the harsh Australian desert landscape, with all odds against them except for a rabbit-proof fence as their guide home. In a moving finale, they are reunited with their mothers and, significantly, their culture. Though it is a specifically Australian story (the Stolen Generations and the White Australia Policy), director Phillip Noyce tells it in such a way that emphasises universal qualities of tragedy and heroism. He opts for an even-handed portrayal of the past, steering clear of images of oppression or subjugation and any chastising of White Culture, and instead emphasises optimism and survival. The film is adapted from a book of the same title by author, Doris Pilkington, daughter of the real-life Molly and ‘Stolen Generation’ victim. Christopher Doyle’s photography and Peter Gabriel’s score give spiritual resonance to moments of emotional intensity, such as the tearing of children from their mothers, the crossing of a daunting barren landscape and the homecoming embrace between mother and daughter. Stars Everlyn Sampi, Tianna Sansbury, Laura Monaghan, Kenneth Branagh, David Gupilil, Deborah Mailman. Also includes the 35-minute documentary “Following the Rabbit Proof Fence” by Darlene Johnson.

results.title: The Last Wave [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Hal McElroy, James McElroy and Ayer Productions
results.brief_description: In this atmospheric mystery thriller a young Sydney lawyer, while defending four First Nations men against a murder charge, is troubled by dreams and is drawn into an underground world, the intimations of an ancient civilization. Step by step a series of apparently random occurrences assume a disturbing pattern. The city becomes a facade for a place of ancient ritual. Cast includes Richard Chamberlain and David Gulpilil and features photography by Russell Boyd. Features a digitally restored soundtrack.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Weir, Hal McElroy, James McElroy and Ayer Productions
results.description: In this atmospheric mystery thriller a young Sydney lawyer, while defending four First Nations men against a murder charge, is troubled by dreams and is drawn into an underground world, the intimations of an ancient civilization. results.title: Lousy Little Sixpence
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Gerald Bostock and Sixpence Productions
results.brief_description: Archival film footage, photographs and the memories of Aboriginal elders weave a moving account of the lives of Aboriginal people and their struggle in the 1930s against the Aborigines Protection Board.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Alec Morgan, Gerald Bostock and Sixpence Productions
results.description: A landmark Australian documentary focusing on Australia’s Stolen Generations, the government policies of forced removal of children from First Nations communities that created them, and the resistance of First Nations people to the theft of their families, lands and cultures.
description_for_label: A landmark Australian documentary focusing on Australia’s Stolen Generations, the government policies of forced removal of children from First Nations communities that created them, and the resistance of First Nations people to the theft of their families, lands and cultures.

results.title: Country Outcasts
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
Country outcasts is a small pop band made up from a number of talented First Nations people who have spent their lives in a wholly urbanised environment. This film is the story of a tour that this band makes through the outback, and the thoughts and feelings that are aroused within these city dwellers when they meet other First Nations peoples in Central Australia.

results.title: Australian Aborigines: living off the land
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land this film shows how local First Nations people live on native animals and plants.
